DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold Lower
Eds: AMer planned by 5:30 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: The dollar finished lower against major currencies in Europe Thursday in light pre-holiday trading. Gold prices also fell. Currency strategists said there was no underlying reason for the dollar's behavior, though some U.S.-based strategists said talk of lower interest rates in the United States may have played a role. A drop in interest rates would make dollar-denominated investments worth less. The U.S. invasion of Panama and unrest in Romania appeared to have had little impact on the U.S. currency, money brokers said. In London, the British pound rose to $1.6125 from $1.6052 late Wednesday. Other late dollar rates in Europe vs. late Wednesday: 1.7250 West German marks, down from 1.7355; 1.5575 Swiss francs, down from 1.5585; 5.8955 French francs, down from 5.9165; 1.9560 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9720; 1,287.50 Italian lire, down from 1,288.00; 1.1605 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1625. In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.46 yen to a closing 143.77 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 143.68 yen. Gold fell in London to a late bid price of $412.75 a troy ounce from 413.50 dollars bid late Wednesday. In Zurich, the metal was unchanged at a bid $413. Gold in Hong Kong fell 70 cents to close at a bid $411.34. Silver bullion rose in London to a late bid of $5.57 a troy ounce, vs. $5.56 late Wednesday.
